properties.text:
TYPO3 Neos 1.0

Changing the world of web content management. TYPO3 Neos 1.0 has been released.

properties.source:
• TYPO3 Neos 1.0

    Changing the world of web content management. TYPO3 Neos 1.0 has been released.
properties.title: Untitled

properties.text:
TYPO3 Neos is the next-generation open source content management system made by the TYPO3 community. Neos is based on the PHP framework TYPO3 Flow.

From now on, the TYPO3 community provides two different CMS products: TYPO3 CMS and TYPO3 Neos. The popular TYPO3 CMS will continue to be developed, upgraded and enhanced. TYPO3 CMS and TYPO3 Neos have different qualities. For some projects, TYPO3 CMS might be the best choice while for others, Neos is able to show its strength. 

You should choose between TYPO3 CMS and TYPO3 Neos based on your project and workflow needs. We will continue making it as easy as possible to understand our products and produce the information needed to choose wisely between them.
Read full release notes of the current release

Requirements will change during the lifecycle of your product. This is why we put a lot of effort into making TYPO3 Neos as easily extendable as possible.

For more advanced use-cases you can use the power of the TYPO3 Flow application framework to add new functionality.

The most basic way of editing content in Neos is available by just clicking what you want to change, working out the changes and pressing the publish button. Then your changes are live. You will see the content changes in the actual design. 

If you need to edit SEO data next to the content, Neos provides an inspector for that.

If you need more, the inspector will be expandable to the full screen providing the user with all property options.

That’s not enough? Create custom backend modules.

And if even that is not enough, underlying Neos, we have Flow – a first-class web application framework which will enable you to build applications that can be integrated with your other systems.

Neos will blend in seamlessly with your website so you as an editor don't have to re-think in order to edit your content. It is our philosophy to reduce the amount of cognitive load to make editing content fun again.

You don‘t need training to edit content in Neos – you already know how to do it. You just click on the part you want to edit – and start. But since publishing projects have very different authoring needs, there is no only way of editing content in Neos.

Either use the full In-Place editing or use what we call Raw Content editing. Raw Content is like having a distraction-free authoring application right inside your CMS – where all the templates are stripped away.

Raw Content mode also makes reusing content across channels more efficient because editors don't spend time perfecting content to match the template. Instead they can focus on the pure words and images while working with a tailored authoring interface.

The Preview Central is where you build your preview templates. If you want your editors to always check three different representations of their content before publishing, then this is easily done in Neos.  

The Preview Central is right next to your editing modes in TYPO3 Neos. You can quickly switch back and forth between editing and previewing.

When you create responsive websites, your CMS should naturally aid you by being responsive as well.

But TYPO3 Neos goes further than that – it will automatically adjust your images for your audiences using progressive enhancement.

Your websites will load faster, feel more fluid and generate a better user experience than websites built with any other CMS on the market.

Since the advanced content editing mechanisms in TYPO3 Neos work together with your website you can change your contents directly within a responsive viewport – getting immediate results and reducing the time of testing your contents on different devices.

Apart from that TYPO3 Neos does not force you to build your website in a special way. Just create your templates - Neos will take care of the rest.

Since TYPO3 Flow is cloud-ready, so is TYPO3 Neos. TYPO3 Neos scales with your business and your demands. You plan an intense marketing campaign? Simply add as many servers as needed to your environment.

This is all made possible with TYPO3 Surf, enabling zero-downtime deployment and making it easy to set up identical servers.

Outrun the competition using TYPO3 Neos' advanced semantic features.

With TYPO3 Neos, creating custom content elements is a breeze - with whatever markup you need. So go ahead and embed RDFa, Microformats or schema.org attributes inside your templates - whatever fits best to your use-case.

properties.title: Standing on the shoulders of a giant

properties.text:
TYPO3 Neos is the successor of the world-class CMS, TYPO3.


We took the experience of more than 500.000 websites built in TYPO3 CMS and used our collective expertise to make a new kind of CMS.
properties.title: Untitled

properties.text:
Being built upon the most advanced PHP framework to date – TYPO3 Flow – makes your websites ready for whatever the future holds for you.

TYPO3 Flow is secure by default, keeping your developers focussed on their main task - building your application - without having to worry about low level implementations.

The „code once - run everywhere“ approach of TYPO3 Flow makes the move from the application to the website very simple.

Whether you start with your website and build the applications from there or you have your application and need content management added to it – TYPO3 Neos and TYPO3 Flow got your back.

TYPO3 Neos enables you to export and import website content. You can easily move content between development, staging and production.

Additionally, Neos is deployable through Surf – the standard deployment solution of  TYPO3. Surf makes changes to functionality in your projects reproducible and highly reliable.
properties.title: Untitled
What do others say about Neos

properties.text: Deane Barker from gadgetopia.com shares his thoughts about our new CMS after a demonstration of TYPO3 Neos:
Karen McGrane, the author of Content Strategy for Mobile, gives her impression of TYPO3 Neos:

TYPO3 Neos Alpha 6 contains lots of improvements, where most of them were incorporated during the code sprint at de-cix in Frankfurt. Main highlights are improved content editing, Plugin Views, features in TypoScript, a new demo site, improved security and lots of bugfixes and stability improvements.

Some changes are breaking, but there is a code migration for many of them. Read on for more information and a detailed list of changes in the release notes.

First install composer like this:

curl -s https://getcomposer.org/installer | php

Now continue with the following steps - you might have done some of them already for the previous alphas, feel free to adjust and skip as needed.
properties.title: Untitled

properties.text:
• Go to your htdocs directory and download the Neos base distribution with all the dependencies:
    cd /your/htdocs/
php /path/to/composer.phar create-project --dev --stability alpha typo3/neos-base-distribution TYPO3-Neos-1.0-alpha6
  • Set up a virtual host inside your apache.conf, and then restart apache:
    NameVirtualHost *:80 # if needed

    <VirtualHost *:80>
        DocumentRoot "/your/htdocs/TYPO3-Neos-1.0-alpha6/Web/"
        # skip the following line for development
        SetEnv FLOW_CONTEXT Production
        ServerName neos.demo
    </VirtualHost>
  • Add an entry to /etc/hosts:
    127.0.0.1 neos.demo
  • Go to http://neos.demo/setup and follow the on-screen instructions!

By using composer, you can update an existing installation to the recent alpha version, without having to create a new project.

cd /installation-root/
composer require "typo3/neos:1.0.0-alpha6"
composer require "typo3/neosdemotypo3org:1.0.0-alpha6"
composer require "typo3/sitekickstarter:1.0.0-alpha6"
# Remember to flush the caches afterwards
./flow flow:cache:flush --force
properties.title: Untitled

properties.text: By using composer, you can switch to the most recent master, in order to test the latest changes:
properties.title: Untitled

properties.text: TYPO3 Neos Alpha 5 features lots of smaller improvements, as being listed in the release notes.
properties.title: Untitled

properties.text: TYPO3 Neos Alpha 4 features lots of great improvements, as being listed in the release notes.
properties.title: Untitled

properties.text: • Alpha 4 has a bug preventing multi-site setups to work properly. As workaround, re-run the setup tool and select clear existing sites if you want to switch between sites (e.g. between the demo site and your custom one). We're investigating and will fix this soon.
properties.title: Untitled

properties.text: And finally arrives alpha 3 which concentrated on stabilizing the content editing and UI of Neos. Additionally some groundwork for future features was put into place. This release is properly tagged and can be fetched through composer. You can follow the steps described for 1.0-alpha2 below, just replace all occurrences of "alpha2" with "alpha3". As soon as the packing process is finished we will also link to archive files (zip, tar) on sourceforge. All changes since alpha 2 are listed in the changelog.
properties.title: Untitled

properties.text: It took us longer than we hoped, but here it is: Neos 1.0 alpha 2! This time it is a properly tagged release you can fetch through composer. We have summarized the changes since alpha 1 for your reading pleasure.
properties.title: Untitled

properties.text: We are proud to finally present to you TYPO3 Neos 1.0 Alpha 1, ready for your consumption!
properties.title: Untitled

properties.text:
• Download TYPO3 Neos 1.0 Alpha 1 and unzip it to your htdocs directory.
  • Set up a virtual host inside your apache.conf, and then restart apache:
    NameVirtualHost *:80 # if needed

    <VirtualHost *:80>
        DocumentRoot "/your/htdocs/TYPO3-Neos-1.0-alpha1/Web/"
        # skip the following line for development
        SetEnv FLOW_CONTEXT Production
        ServerName neos.demo
    </VirtualHost>
  • Add an entry to /etc/hosts:
    127.0.0.1 neos.demo
  • Go to http://neos.demo/setup and follow the on-screen instructions!

Enjoy!
properties.title: Untitled

properties.text: We collected questions regarding installation and usage of TYPO3 Neos. Can't find your question on this page? Feel free to send us a message and we will help you out and add the question here.

properties.title: How can I use the semantic features in Neos? I can't find any hint in the user interface or editor.

properties.text:
Neos is semantic ready, as it is possible to create any markup you'd like inside your content element. Thus, creating content elements which adhere to microformats, RDFa or schema.org is a breeze.

Furthermore, CreateJS allows for future UI integration of semantic editing features. For details have a look at Rens' and Henri's presentation slides about CreateJS and Neos from T3CON12, or watch the recorded presentation.

Neos 1.0 still comes without any page caches – all rendering is done for each hit. That’s why we currently suggest to use Varnish in front of TYPO3 Neos.

We will work on a PHP-based page cache and native Edge Side Include support for Varnish in the future.

properties.title: Where can I find merchandise for Neos?

properties.text: For now, we have some nice t-shirts and clothes in the TYPO3 spreadshirt shop.

properties.title: What is the official hash tag for Neos?

properties.text: The hash tag we use for Neos and where we will also look for questions and other input is: #TYPO3Neos.

properties.title: Why can't Neos do this or that?

properties.text:
First off, we want to do everything right from the start. The idea is that whenever we release a feature it will be as bulletproof as humanly possible.

This ideal of course somewhat limits the amount of features we can put out at a time, but we put quality over quantity.

Furthermore, due to the big flexibility of Neos and Flow, it’s often possible to create new features as separate packages – so we need your help to build the features you need. If you feel a feature is missing and you’d like to build it, please get in touch with the team and we can provide you some guidance.

properties.title: Can I import my website from TYPO3 CMS?

properties.text:
We need to distinguish between content import and template/extension import.

Template/Extension import is not possible, and will never be. However, if you use Extbase and Fluid in TYPO3 CMS already, it will be easier for you to port this code to Neos.

Content import is currently not possible.

However, while we do not have content import ready as of today, we are already experimenting with different approaches of a content migration process and think that pages and the standard TYPO3 CMS content elements like Text or Image will be importable in the future. Additionally, we’ll make sure that the conversion process is extensible, so you can adjust it if you use special FCEs or the like.

Here, you'll find some step-by-step instructions on how to learn Neos.

We plan to greatly extend this section in the future.
Head over to the Download page for the installation instructions. As soon as you have Neos installed and ran the setup tool, you will have the Neos Demo Site available to play with.

You can find the TYPO3 Neos Demo Site inside the Packages/Sites/TYPO3.NeosDemoTypo3Org folder of your Neos distribution.

The Neos Demo Site follows all best-practices for TYPO3 Neos, so we suggest that you analyze and modify it.

Now, it's time to check out the Neos Documentation, most specifically:

  • The Neos Integrator Cookbook contains short solutions to many common requirements.
  • The Neos Integrator Guide contains full explanations of TYPO3CR, TypoScript and the whole rendering process.

We need your help expanding the documentation! It is currently stored inside the Neos Git Repository; so you can push your suggested changes to review.typo3.org as usual.

If you need help in setting up everything you need, get in touch with the team and we can help you out.

The Neos team is improving the master plan of the Neos user experience while agencies all over the world are slowly beginning to do their own web sites using the alpha version of Neos. We have in Neos a beautiful baby - but it still needs to be taught manners and raised well.

So, the team has been asking itself the simple question: How will large labyrinthine organizations work with web sites in 2017? 

We’re also asking leading user experience and CMS experts from around the world the same question, getting them to challenge our thoughts.

…Plus, we’d love to hear the answers of everyone in the community!
properties.title: Untitled
How do you think enterprises will build and maintain their complex sites in 2017?

properties.text:
If you’d like to take part in this discussion, please join the Neos forum and share your thoughts. The input we get will directly influence the way we plan future functionality of Neos.

We’ll share some of the inspirational thoughts that will appear throughout the process coming from both the TYPO3 community and outsiders.
properties.title: Untitled

properties.caption: Neos team discussing the structuring of the general user experience at the May '13 code sprint
properties.title: Untitled

properties.text:
The master plan of the first production-ready versions of Neos is pretty set by now.

But as Neos is a CMS that will work especially well for the larger, more complex solutions, we’re looking for all the help we can get in prioritizing future features and how we structure the user interface to handle e.g. complex localization or digital asset management.

Read on if you’d like to get insight into the inner workings of the user experience plan.
properties.title: Untitled

properties.text:
The Neos team is putting together all the generic design interface specifications into a single document that will allow future designers and developers achieve a consistent user experience across any kind of plugin or module.

If you are an experienced application interface designer, this is therefore a perfect time to help out.

Write to Rasmus (rasmus[at]typo3[dot] org) if you want to get in touch.
properties.title: Untitled

properties.text:
In only few years from now, the world will have entirely new cities. Cities whose development has not even started. Cities that can draw from all we know about livability and functionality. The same goes for websites. Major websites will be built with the tools we’re constructing today. But we don't know how they will be like. Just think of how different sites were 3 years ago.

For both cities and websites, one basic rule counts: Things are constantly changing and can never be fully anticipated.

The inspiration from urban planning permeates our UX master plan, giving us crucial guidelines for structuring everything we know  - and making room for all the future change we don’t know.
properties.title: Untitled

properties.text:
In 2017, Neos will have been in use for years as a trusted tool to build and maintain complex websites. Many extensions were added and ideas we cannot imagine today will have been added to the software.

Yet, today we need to decide on major parts of the experience and the interface. If everything is added on an ad hoc basis - because it just feels right to put a button here and a menu there - you would end up with slums of the interface.


We've planned the Neos backend like you plan cities - with lots of room for change. Regardless of you being an integrator, a developer, a content editor or a site manager, the overall experience of using Neos provides for a productive life inside the interface.

We’ve put emphasis on concepts, in line with the feature set, that will provide for great personalization of both the backend workflow and the web experience that publishers will be able to deliver. The principles we've chosen can guide later alterations to the interface.
properties.title: Untitled

properties.text:
1. Create boundaries: Clearly separate different kinds of components to make users know where to look.
  2. Thinking is King: It’s your thinking that determines the web experience for your users, not the CMS.
  3. Distribute capacity: Provide power when needed.
  4. Simulate before publishing: Experience what your users will experience.
  5. Plan for change: Make the interface adaptable to reorganizing.
properties.title: Untitled
Clearly seperate different kinds of components to make users know where to look

properties.text:
When we looked at the city as an analogy for websites, we looked for boundaries to help us structure the Neos backend. In cities, there’s a very hard boundary between private and public. With that thinking we made a plan for where things belong.

A street is not a home. You drive fast on highways, not on the sidewalks. Likewise, we’ve planned the backend experience to give everything a natural home in the interface and in workflows. A module is in the menu, a node of every type is in the new Navigate menu, meta-data is in the Inspector -  and you edit your content seamlessly in the content itself. 

These major parts will function as our hard boundaries preventing flooding of the interface. Everything logically structured to make sure developers will know where to put new components - making users know where to find everything.
properties.title: Untitled
It’s your thinking that determines the web experience for your users, not the CMS

properties.text:
When planning a city, you need to think. Often, content management systems will tell you that they’ve done all the thinking for you.

In Neos, you’ll be able to build great websites with a CMS that doesn't impose a certain process or a particular business logic. Neos doesn’t compete with other software that makes it super-easy to build a quick blog or a photo gallery. It is meant for more complex solutions.

Yet at the same time, we use UI design principles from the world of easy-to-use web experiences. It’ll be up to you to decide how you work with it.

You can build a web application first, then later decide to use Neos as a thin layer of content editing on top - or the other way around. The interface must facilitate such variation of use.
properties.title: Untitled

properties.text:
The distribution of power in a city makes sure that everyone gets what they need. You don’t power a shed in the way you power a nuclear plant. The ultra-simple editing makes editors center their attention on content.

If you need to add SEO data next to the content, Neos has an inspector that opens up for that kind of functionality. Just a bit more power, one step at a time... If you need more, the inspector will be expandable to the full backend screen providing the user with all the options.

That’s not enough? Create custom backend modules. And if even that's not enough, underlying Neos, we have Flow - a first-class web framework that enables you to build web applications that integrate with your other systems.

We don’t get in your way. We just provide open, flexible, powerful tools and a mindset of how to work with them. Everything connected in interfaces that don't interfere with the process of your business.
properties.title: Untitled
Experience what your users will experience

properties.text:
With Neos, you will be able to view and preview your content in different ways. Switch to fullscreen mode to experience exactly what your users will experience. If your designer is not finished with the design, you can also make content editors start working with content in wireframe mode and apply templates later.

If you want editors to preview how SEO metadata for a page will appear in a Google search, you should be able to extend the preview for the editor. Same goes for mobile preview, tablet or any other preview you need. The longer-term plan is to collect all these views in one View menu.
properties.title: Untitled
Make the interface adaptable to reorganizing

properties.text:
Cities change constantly - and websites do the same. We cannot fully predict how the web will work in the years to come. We're working hard to make the interface and the frontend development of the backend as flexible as possible.

As everything is logically structured in the backend, later rearrangements of the interface will be a lot easier.
properties.title: Untitled

properties.text:
The Neos team is putting together all the generic design interface specifications into a single document that will allow future designers and developers achieve a consistent user experience across any kind of plugin or module.

If you are an experienced application interface designer, this is therefore a perfect time to help out. Write to Rasmus (rasmus[at]typo3[dot]org) if you want to get in touch.

Aske Ertmann & Rasmus Skjoldan
properties.title: Untitled

properties.caption: Enter caption here
properties.alternativeText: Neos - A CMS for editors to love

properties.text:
As a client using TYPO3, have you ever had the feeling it was too difficult to give us feedback on our products?
This is for you.

• what would you focus on when building a brand new WCMS?
  • what features will be the most important in years to come?
  • what would be the optimal user experience for you as an editor or site manager?
properties.title: Untitled
Clients of TYPO3 get to influence development directly

properties.text:
One of the great things about being a client of an open source community-based product is that you get to influence the feature-set and the entire development of the software you depend on directly.

Over the years, an abundance of client feedback has transformed TYPO3 CMS. This process naturally goes on.
properties.title: Untitled
Your chance to impact the CMS of the future

properties.text:
As the feature set of the first version of Neos is virtually fixed, we can now focus on planning ahead - beyond the 1.0 release.

TYPO3 Neos is already being used for real projects - but to use it for larger, complex solutions, we need to plan ahead into a future of a relatively unknown territory. For that to work well, we are collecting input from various sources:

  • ...our strong development community
  • ...the business leaders of TYPO3 agencies
  • ...first-hand feedback coming from all the daily client contact we have on the Neos team
  • ...outside experts beyond the TYPO3 community are being consulted to challenge our thoughts

Now is the time to gather a group of experienced clients to iteratively influence our thinking and planning.
properties.title: Untitled

properties.text:
We have already made contact to the first major clients interested in taking part in the follow-group, giving continuous feedback on Neos development.

But we need about 3-5 more enterprise-level clients who manage large, complex web projects.
properties.title: Untitled

properties.text:
As part of the follow-group this is what will happen:

  • When we have major new overall plans, features or UI's - we send it to you and ask for your feedback.
  • Giving feedback is quick: Via Skype or Google hangout, we quickly brief you on the concept or feature up for discussion. You tell us what you think about it - and what you believe the implications of the changes would be to you, your content editors or your developers.
  • The feedback is then discussed on the team and translated into changes.
  • If you like and prefer another level of openness, we can feature your organization, build cases together and help tell your stories - it's entirely up to you.
properties.title: Untitled

properties.text:
• Direct influence on development will help make sure you get a highly usable WCMS platform in the future.
  • Access to expert web developers, architects and UX'ers that can give advice on when and how to start using Neos and Flow.
  • Networking with other clients with shared interests in WCMS.

If you're interested, just mail rasmus[at]typo3.org and tell us about your organization and how you worked with CMSes before.
properties.title: Untitled
Predicting and shaping the future of web content management

properties.text:
What kind of CMS tools and processes will be important in 4 years from now? How can we plan our software today so that it is highly relevant in years to come? Such questions are naturally essential to the planning of a new CMS, based on our experience of the +500.000 site strong TYPO3 CMS.

Here, experts like content strategist, Karen McGrane, vendor-neutral client advisors like Janus Boye and Perttu Tolvanen of North Patrol - as well as large CMS clients such as the Danish Broadcasting Corporation - have all given us their views on the future of content management.
properties.title: Untitled

properties.text:
On our way to the 1.0 release of TYPO3 Neos, the team building the open source CMS realized we had to take planning much further. We couldn't just focus on getting 1.0 ready.

That simple realization made us start curating this collection of forecasts. About how the web will be built in 2017.
properties.title: Untitled
Hi future! How will the web be built in 2017?

properties.text:
We have spent a good deal of time asking leading experts in the field about how they see the future of WCMS. Mixing their great experience and knowledge with our own thoughts on how the WCMS field is changing, we now can better plan beyond our first production-ready release of TYPO3 Neos.

In company with this goal, we also wanted to tell the story about how much change is going on in the CMS world.
properties.title: Untitled

properties.source: <iframe src="http://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/embed_code/24491044?rel=0" width="340" height="290" frameborder="0" marginwidth="0" marginheight="0" scrolling="no" style="border:1px solid #CCC;border-width:1px 1px 0;margin-bottom:5px" allowfullscreen> </iframe>
properties.title: Untitled

properties.text:
Karen McGrane, Janus Boye, Alain Veuve, Perttu Tolvanen, Boris Kraft, Kian Gould, Martin Goldbach Olsen, Jacob Floyd, Mikkel Staunsholm, Olivier Dobberkau, Daniel Hinderink, Christian Badse, Robert Lemke, Jan-Erik Revsbech, Sebastian Kurfuerst, Anders Bendix Kiel, Christian Nilson, Rasmus Skjoldan

(Please note that all statements have kindly been given to us specifically for this collection.)
properties.title: Untitled

properties.text:
Apart from this collection of thoughts on the future, many things are going on in the continuous planning of TYPO3 Neos. We're quite far in establishing a client follow-group that will help us make sure that we are building a tool for real client needs and not just our own itches. We have been conducting interviews, workshops and meetings with leading experts - among others with Head of User Research at the UK Government Digital Service, Leisa Reichelt, Yat Hui of Urban Beings and Information Architects Inc.

Our development releases also showed a lot of the technical progress taking place - and the newly revised user interface, guided by our user experience master plan. With the release of the first production-ready version we also experience the launch of bigger real-life projects.
properties.title: Untitled

properties.text:
We hope many people will share and debate what some of the implications of these predictions may be. On Twitter using #TYPO3Neos or on the TYPO3 Neos forum and mailing list.

Questions about the 2017 WCM Forecast can be sent to TYPO3 Neos designer, Rasmus Skjoldan at rasmus[at]typo3.org.
properties.title: Untitled

properties.text:
While the release of TYPO3 Neos 1.0 is an important point in our development timeline, we have lots of ideas on how to progress.

Quite some exciting features will follow. This page shall give an overview about the upcoming areas we will work on.
properties.title: Untitled
Multi-language support in TYPO3CR and User Interface

properties.text:
Handling multiple languages and areas with proper fallback support is a key feature of every advanced CMS. While we thought about multi-language features right from the first concept, it is not implemented in TYPO3CR yet and the User Interface. We will close this gap and support multiple languages and locales.

Other than that, the user interface should also be localized, both the backend as well as the content editing experience. This is rather straight-forward, as TYPO3 Flow already has a sophisticated localization system in place which just has to be used.
properties.title: Untitled

properties.text:
There are still some open tasks regarding the structure and test coverage of our JavaScript code base – we want to achieve the same level of perfection we put into the Flow and Neos PHP code.

Additionally, now that composer forms the foundation of package management, the foundation is laid to separate Neos into different packages for different concerns. Ideally, every backend module should become its own package to be easily maintainable.
properties.title: Untitled

properties.text:
In bigger projects, it is important to define fine-grained access rules on who is allowed to see and edit which parts of the website. We would like to add permissions in TYPO3CR on the page and document level.

Furthermore, we'd like to provide a frontend login working out of the box, allowing to put parts of the website behind a login.

Because of the content-first approach of Neos, you'll end up with lots of node types, where only very few make sense globally.

That's why we'd like to make it configurable where a node type is allowed to be placed.

After years of development we need time off, so we will go into REST.

Work on a more REST-like interface for Neos has already been started, and will be continued shortly after the 1.0 release. We aim for a solid and generic interface to access the content repository.

We aim for being able to transfer TYPO3 CMS pages and the standard Content Elements like Text or Image. Furthermore, the conversion process should be adjustable to be usable for  Flexible Content Elements or custom content.

We'd like to add a page cache to Neos, so that it can be used without Varnish.

Furthermore, we have lots of ideas on how we can improve performance, so that will definitely be a focus in the future.

From the very beginning, Neos rendering has been built to allow for rendering only parts of a web page. However, we do not expose this functionality to the user yet.

By allowing partial rendering from the outside, Neos  – in combination with Edge Side Includes and Varnish  – will allow to build highly customized experiences without sacrificing performance.

While we are able to work with multiple content appearances right from the start, we did not tackle customized content for each channel yet. We'd especially like to allow arbitrary conditions to be used in rendering; i.e. changing a header image depending on the current weather or the user's geographical location.

As already stated, Neos is using annotations to access the content on a page. We do so using VIE and CreateJS.

In the upcoming period we will see how to collaborate on decoupled content management with CreateJS, and how we can add extra editors to Neos to link semantic metadata to content with Annotate.js.

We have created the TYPO3 Expose package to be an extensible base package for listing and editing arbitrary records, be it content in Neos or arbitrary domain objects of any Flow application.

While the package is roughly working, there are still lots of details in terms of user interaction that need to be fixed.
properties.title: Untitled

properties.text:
We know that content management of today is different than it was a few years ago. Dealing with high load, distributed services is very common. In TYPO3 Neos, we want to make our export/import functionality more versatile to use and also create a service that allows synchronization of content across different web sites.

Because of its robust foundations, clean abstraction layers and the use of universally unique identifiers (UUIDs), this is a lot easier to implement than with classical web applications.
properties.title: Untitled

properties.text:
TYPO3 Neos cannot be built without participation of many dedicated community members – we need your help to implement your favourite feature.

Just get in touch with us so we can bring you up to speed.
properties.title: Untitled

properties.text:
We're always looking for new contributors. If you can help in one of the following areas, please get in touch with us!

  • Code
  • Testing
  • Usability
  • Documentation
  • Feature ideas
  • Anything else useful for TYPO3 Neos

We're looking forward to hearing from you!
properties.title: Untitled

properties.text:
Offer contribution

Want to offer your contribution? Please get in touch with us on mailing lists or IRC (irc.freenode.net, channel #typo3-flow or #typo3-neos) so we can find someone to mentor your contribution.

properties.caption: Contributors and team members alike worked hand in hand during a Neos codesprint in Copenhagen
properties.alternativeText: TYPO3 Neos team members and contributors

properties.text:
TYPO3 Neos and TYPO3 Flow, originally started by Robert Lemke and Karsten Dambekalns, are built by an ever-growing team of awesome people.

But team members are not the only people who are contributing; many users and other project supporters are helping Neos to grow through a steady stream of high quality contributions.

Feel inspired and invited to join us - even if you only start by fixing a bunch of typos in our documentation!
properties.title: Untitled

properties.text:
We, the team working on Neos and Flow, would like to be able to grow. We want to make it easy for new contributors to join us in building the coolest CMS built on our top notch PHP framework.

We also want to make sure everyone is recognized for their contributions. It should be natural to recognize both active and inactive contributors while we keep the team at a manageable size.

Finally, projects like TYPO3 Neos have plenty of things that need to be organized. Since they've got to be done, we want to give a group of people responsibility for these organizational tasks. To make all of this possible, we have set several groups and roles.
properties.title: Untitled

properties.text:
The members of the Neos team base their work, communication and being together on core values like humility, respect, responsibility, and trust.

We try to remove all technical barriers and refrain from creating fine grained rule sets and procedures because we trust team members to use their rights and power responsibly.

Team members adhere to the Code of Conduct of the TYPO3 Project.
We also follow these guiding principles: common sense and good intentions.

There is a dedicated page explaining our core values.
properties.title: Untitled

properties.text:
Contributor

Those community members who would like to get involved into the respective project are invited to start contributing code, design, documentation or provide help by other means. No one needs to ask for permission to get involved and start contributing as long as they can identify with our core values and technical principles.

Our more experienced contributors will help new contributors with the first steps in our mailing lists and IRC channels. Anyone who contributes to the project is called a Contributor.

A Contributor …

  • will get credit in a list of contributors for the respective product they worked on.
  • can push changes to Gerrit and review change sets but cannot submit code to master.
  • is - technically - not (yet) part of the Neos team.

Active Contributor

An active contributor regularly contributes high-quality code, documentation, design work, or something similar. Existing Active Contributors may invite a contributor to join them as an active contributor through consensus-based decision.

The sum of all Active Contributors forms the Neos Team, formerly known as the Neos Core Team.

An Active Contributor ...

  • has deep knowledge of the product.
  • provides recent, recurring, high quality contribution.
  • is eligible for a typo3.org email address.
  • has basically full access and administrative rights to the git repositories, websites, social media accounts etc. like any other member of the team.
  • uses these access rights with great care and responsibility.
  • represents the project responsibly and prefers to solve disputes or disagreements within the team.

The Neos Team is led and important tasks are coordinated by a group of Active Contributors which form the Coordination Group. You can watch the progress of tasks tackled by the coordination team at their project at forge.typo3.org. The positions in this group may vary depending on the jobs to be done. In the beginning we’ll start with the following:

Project Leader

The Project Leader is responsible for the leadership of the project and the product vision. Acting as the user's advocate, this person maintains the high level view on the feature set. A Co-Leader acts as a stand-in for the Project Leader in case of unavailability.

Quality Manager

The Quality Manager is our chief nitpicker and makes sure that Neos meets our high quality standards. In particular, this person is responsible for coordinating the team of Quality Guardians and overseeing the release process.

Community Contact

The Community Contact lends an ear to the needs of users, existing and potential contributors and solves possible disputes. This position includes staying in touch with the TYPO3 project's community manager and seeking to maintain a healthy community around Neos.

Public Relations Manager

The Public Relations Manager coordinates the promotion of Neos with the Marketing Team, acts as a press contact, pushes news and takes care of the product website.
properties.title: Untitled

properties.text:
Treasurer

The treasurer acts as a budget owner and coordinates all efforts regarding funding and raising of funds for the Neos project.

A Release Manager schedules and coordinates contributions for a specific release as well as any release announcements and other communication about the release. This position includes the responsibility for a specific major or minor product release, including all of its patch level releases, throughout the lifetime of that maintained version.

The Release Manager is appointed by the Active Contributors in agreement with the Quality Manager.

A Quality Guardian watches over the overall project consistency and stability. Each commit which changes the behavior of the product (for example introducing a new configuration option, a new feature, breaking backwards compatibility and so on) needs to be acknowledged by a Quality Guardian. There is no technical barrier which would stop Active Contributors bypassing a Quality Guardian so this mechanism again is built on trust and responsibility.

The Quality Guardians are chosen by the Active Contributors and the Quality Manager based on merit and a deep experience and understanding of the product and its vision.

For all packages which are part of the respective product, a package maintainer is appointed. The Package Maintainer is the one to contact before submitting functional changes the first time or if you are in doubt about a certain feature fitting into the package’s concept.

Are you a skilled designer, developer, editor, manager, communicator or have an unusual talent which is missing in our team?

We'll gladly help you to get started and become a contributor by mentoring and sharing our experiences with you.

To get started, start playing with Neos and Flow, then come talk with us via our mailing list or IRC channel. For more hints on how to start contributing to the project, check out our contribution page.
properties.title: Untitled

properties.text: This is living stuff that describes a living team full of living people. We are alive. We can clarify or adapt anything here to better reflect who we are. This stuff is not rules or procedures. We recorded these thoughts October 2013 at the Neos Codesprint in Frankfurt.

We are members of the Neos team. Each one of us is unique. But we share a set of values that make it fun to work as a team. These are our values. They motivate us and light our internal fire. Our values guide how we communicate and how we make decisions. We are agile. This is who we are.

Humility

We all make mistakes. Constructive criticism is always welcome.

Respect

We all have different opinions, different personalities, and different ways to approach problems.

Responsibility

We consider the consequences of our actions, our code, and our communication.

Trust

We trust other team members to make the right decision even when we are absent.

Humility

We love to learn from each other.

Respect 

We are passionate about creating great software.

Responsibility 

We value quality and excellence over mediocre but fast achievements.

Trust

We strive to improve ourselves and the project.

Humility

We discuss vividly, and we do not take it personally.

When I have something to discuss, I bring it up.

Respect

We disagree, but we do not start flame wars.

When I disagree with you, I will talk with you respectfully.

Responsibility 

Outside the team, we are unified in our communication.

Our communication is consistent.

Trust

We trust each other to speak for the team.

When I present or speak, I speak for the team, not just for my own benefit. I might be a team delegate, and I might look like a team leader to people outside the team, but I recognize that there are no fixed team roles, and I respect my fellow team members.

Humility

We can learn from each other. We make decision processes transparent.

It is okay to reverse the decisions of others. No one can expect to get their way every time.

Respect

We listen to and value each other's arguments and feedback.

Seek the input of others.

Responsibility

We give each other permission to make decisions, and we expect each other to make those decisions quickly and responsibly.

Use common sense instead of fine-grained rules.

Trust

We trust all team members to make decisions. We trust each other to decide with good intentions.

Not everybody needs to be involved to make decisions.

Humility

We might make mistakes, but we take small steps. We can always adjust our course.

It is okay to reverse the decisions of others.

Respect

We celebrate both joint and individual achievements. We respect each team member as a person, not just for the role they are filling right now.

Acknowledge others and give credit where credit is due.

Responsibility

We move forward quickly. We make decision processes transparent.

No official team roles or hierarchy. No bureaucratic procedures.

Trust

We might use informal polls, but we do not have a formal voting process.

Not everybody needs to be involved to make decisions.

Although people from all over the world are working remotely on TYPO3 Neos, a lot of progress was reached at real-life events. They are not only great for discussions and decisions, but also for developing at lightspeed.
Apart from working on Neos, code-sprints are also a great opportunity to meet and exchange with old and new friends.

In October the team met in Frankfurt, kindly hosted by DE-CIX, who not only sponsored the meeting room but also the accommodation for all participants - thanks a lot! 24 people from 7 countries attended the sprint and worked together on Neos, most of them for the full 5 days of the sprint, resulting in over 150 merged fixes and features. Sebastian prepared a nice video with impressions from the code sprint.

  • Wiki Page

In May 2013 a code sprint took place in Karlsruhe where we worked on the work packages and discussed some topics for the stable release. The goals were to find solutions for all the technical questions that were still unclear and to have clearly defined goals for the stable release.

  • Google+ Event Page
  • Wiki Page

We published some blog posts based on discussions during the sprint:

  • Neos and Flow - An update for the team structure
  • Putting Neos technology into usable form

We had a code sprint at the end of January 2013 to bring TYPO3 Neos closer to a stable release.

  • Google+ Event Page
  • Wiki Page
  • The location was one we had used already in the past.

A blog post with details on what was achieved during the sprint can be found on typo3.org.

Can’t wait to try TYPO3 Neos but don’t want to spend time on installing it? Take a free test drive with a pre-installed version and experience the new feel of content editing:

  • Launchr offers a hosted TYPO3 Neos for testing purposes for free. Just sign-up and take off with Neos.
  • A 30-day trial hosting with a pre-installed Neos is offered by Mittwald.

If your company is also offering a test environment for TYPO3 Neos and you would like to be listed here, please get in touch with us.
properties.title: Untitled
TYPO3 Neos 1.0 Beta 1 released
properties.author: Rasmus Skjoldan, Berit Hlubek
properties.teaserText: The entire Neos team is very excited to provide the first Beta release of TYPO3 Neos 1.0. It is an important step towards the final 1.0 release. The Beta provides more stability for early adopters and contains most features of the upcoming release. We expect there won’t be any breaking changes from now until the final release.

properties.text: Download the release of TYPO3 Neos Beta 1
properties.title: Untitled

properties.text:
The speed at which features are stabilized and new functionality can be added has boosted tremendously during the last few months. Our platform is now becoming more and more reliable and steady. That means that the pace of development is naturally increasing now. While approaching the 1.0 stable release, we expect this trend to continue. It is also becoming more and more effortless to include new developers now that the platform is stronger and more balanced.

The user interface has been been improved in many areas and is continuously undergoing refinement. The reorganization of our editing modes and the Preview Central – and also the relabeling of Wireframe mode to Raw Content – did not make it into the Beta 1 but we’re very close to be able to release this important UI change.

The neos.typo3.org website is currently undergoing major rework and will be relaunched soon to show the product in ways that better presents all the massive power of TYPO3 Neos. Both text, structure and design will change greatly to allow us to progressively build the online presence for Neos for both clients, agencies and our community.

The team intends to release more Beta versions before the 1.0 release but not on a specified schedule.

Now that TYPO3 Neos is out of Alpha, the Beta can more safely be used for real projects. More and more agencies and freelancers have started using TYPO3 Neos – for both test and production. If you don’t plan to use it for production just yet, then this Beta release is the perfect time to take it for a spin, see how it all works – and give back input to the team to make sure that the final release will work for all kinds of scenarios.
properties.title: Untitled

properties.text:
• Improved the ease of use for frontend developers and website integrators, e.g. no TypoScript has to be written to create custom content element
  • SEO improvements to prevent duplicate content
  • Cleaner frontend HTML output for a better support of custom templates and various HTML framework
  • Improved stability of content editing and overall user experience
  • Numerous bug fixes and stability improvements

A full list of changes can be found in the release notes.

Please help out giving feedback – and start planning the release parties around the world!

The final TYPO3 Neos 1.0 release is planned for December 10th 2013.

properties.title: TYPO3 Neos Alpha 7 released
properties.author: Berit Hlubek
properties.teaserText: We are happy to announce the release of TYPO3 Neos Alpha 7 at the T3CON13 which will be our last alpha release. With this release we finalized features and bug fixes which were started during the code sprint in Frankfurt and took an important step towards the upcoming beta release. There remains a list of a few blocking issues for the beta release which we plan to resolve shortly.

properties.text: Download the release of TYPO3 Neos Alpha 7
properties.title: Untitled

properties.text:
Here is a short overview of the main improvements of Alpha 7:

  • Support for internal links: Neos now has support for creating internal links, including auto-completion when adding a link.
  • Wireframe Mode improvements: It is now better readable and less prone to conflicts with special elements.
  • Stability improvements like the ability to install Neos in a subfolder, improved handling of errors during rendering and styling fixes
  • Enhancements of TypoScript 2 and FlowQuery
  • Enhancement of the documentation: Like the addition of the integrators cookbook
  • Cleanup of code, UI, default TypoScript files and documentation.

You will find more details about this release in the TYPO3 Neos Alpha 7 Release Notes, which also contain upgrade instructions and an overview of breaking changes.

Enjoy the release,
the TYPO3 Neos Team
properties.title: Untitled
TYPO3 Neos 1.0 released
properties.author: the TYPO3 Neos Team
properties.teaserText: It is with great pride that the TYPO3 community releases the TYPO3 Neos version 1.0. It's been a long haul to get to this point but now, after an only month-long short beta-period, we're now ready with the 1.0 stable release.

properties.text: It is with great pride that the TYPO3 community releases the TYPO3 Neos version 1.0. It's been a long haul to get to this point but now, after an only month-long short beta-period, we're now ready with the 1.0 stable release.
